title: Architect of Labour’s Leftward Shift Wants to Recast Britain’s Economy
text:
John McDonnell, the likely finance minister in a Labour government should it win an election expected this year, speaking last month in London.

LONDON—As the U.K. likely heads for its third nationwide election in four years this fall, the main opposition Labour Party is pushing plans to extend the state’s reach into the economy on a scale not seen in decades. It wants to rewrite a rulebook that it believes created the economic hardship that fueled the Brexit vote.

Labour lawmakers and activists gather this weekend to start their get-together to discuss policy and settle on a new election manifesto. The party has previously pledged to renationalize railways, water companies and the country’s electricity grid.

It has called on the U.K. Treasury to steer private investment into favored industries. It wants workers on company boards and higher taxes on the rich. It has toyed with moving the Bank of England from London to Birmingham.

Behind the party’s shift to the radical left is John McDonnell, 68 years old and a close ally of party leader Jeremy Corbyn. Mr. McDonnell wants to become the U.K.’s first avowedly socialist finance minister in half a century.

Six years ago, he was a nobody in Labour, politically sidelined, recovering from a heart attack and preparing for retirement.

Today, as the party’s powerful economy chief, he is the architect of a bold and controversial plan to reshape the British economy. He recently spoke favorably of banning bankers’ bonuses, imposing a new tax on all financial transactions and jailing advisers who help companies and individuals evade tax.

Mr. McDonnell, a proud Liverpudlian, says he is no firebrand, just a messenger for a new, post-financial-crisis reality, where voters’ economic anxiety is fueling political ferment.

“We’re now in a period of introspection about how the system works,” Mr. McDonnell said in an interview earlier this year in his cluttered office in Westminster. “People are looking at different ideas and socialism has come back onto the agenda.”

British politics is in turmoil. Almost three years of inconclusive wrangling over how to act on the 2016 referendum decision to leave the European Union has ruptured the two main parties and left Parliament in gridlock. The country faces unprecedented constitutional strains, with Queen Elizabeth and the courts at risk of being drawn into the political fray.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson is angling for swift elections to break the logjam and deliver on his “do or die” promise to take Britain out of the EU when the current Brexit deadline expires on Oct. 31.

But opposition parties, Labour included, are wary. They are pushing to delay any poll until November or later to lessen the risk the U.K. leaves the bloc at the end of next month without a negotiated settlement to smooth its withdrawal.

Labour is nevertheless on an election footing. For months, Mr. McDonnell’s treasury team has been working on tax-and-spending plans to implement immediately if Labour wins power. He has been touring provincial towns and cities to hear policy ideas from ordinary folk and work them into Labour’s economic plan.

Mr. McDonnell speaking to union members in London’s Trafalgar Square during a march on May 1. Photo: Wiktor Szymanowicz/NurPhoto/Zuma Press

Some investors fret that Labour policies could over time hurt the U.K. economy more than an abrupt and messy split with the EU. “I think a no-deal Brexit is definitely better than a Corbyn-led government,” said one bond-fund manager in London.

Mr. McDonnell has pushed back against such views with a schmoozing operation others have dubbed the “tea offensive.” He has visited bank boardrooms and executive c-suites and in May attended The Wall Street Journal’s CEO Council in London, seeking to reassure business leaders and financiers that his policies shouldn’t frighten them.

But he hasn’t stinted on criticism. “This government of the bankers and for the bankers is too cut off to notice the millions of people in poverty—and doesn’t care that Tory governments have created this nightmare of modern Britain,” he said last month.

John Mills, a British businessman and a major donor to the Labour Party, said Mr. McDonnell will have to bury his more firebrand rhetoric if the party is elected. “If he is faced with running the country, he is going to have to get on with running the country,” Mr. Mills said.

The son of a Liverpool dockworker and a cleaner, Mr. McDonnell has represented the West London suburb of Hayes and Harlington since 1997. He once worked on a TV assembly line. He and Mr. Corbyn, a close ally, spent decades on the periphery of the Labour Party among a tiny band of hard-left holdouts after former Prime Minister Tony Blair shifted the party closer to the political center.

Like Mr. Corbyn, Mr. McDonnell has courted controversy during a checkered career. He was fired from his job as finance chief of the council that ran London in the 1980s for refusing to implement a government-imposed cap on local taxes. He was once sued for libel by a political rival and settled out of court. He has praised the “sacrifices” made by the Irish Republican Army during its bloody campaign against British rule in Northern Ireland.

Labour Party leader Jeremy Corbyn speaking in the House of Commons earlier this month during the debate of a government motion calling for an early election. Photo: uk parliamentary recording unit//EPA/Shutterstock

Mr. Corbyn vaulted to the leadership of the Labour Party in 2015 thanks to the support of a wave of youthful backers scarred by the financial crisis. Since then the party has sought to tap a wellspring of anger in parts of Britain plagued by insecure work, poor wages and cuts to public services, daily challenges that Labour officials argue contributed to the Brexit vote.

“At the bottom of a recession, it’s all about survival. As we start to come out, and we’re told we’re coming out of recession, and you don’t feel you’re sharing in that, that’s when people really start questioning the system,” Mr. McDonnell said in the interview.

Policies such as public control of railways and utilities are popular with voters, opinion polls show. But Labour is trailing Mr. Johnson’s Conservatives in the polls, with a regular survey of voting intentions by YouGov PLC giving the prime minister’s party a 12-point lead.

Yet those polls suggest the Conservatives will only get 34% of the vote and would struggle to command a majority. That leaves open the prospect of a Labour-led administration cobbled together with smaller opposition groups, such as the Liberal Democrats and the Scottish Nationalist Party.

Labour’s political opponents and some pollsters say the party’s main handicap is Mr. Corbyn, who is wildly popular among the enthusiastic young Labour supporters who swept him to power in 2015 but less so with the wider public. According to a poll published on Sept. 17 by YouGov, just 21% of Britons holding a positive opinion of him and 70% a negative one. The party has also struggled to shake off allegations that Mr. Corbyn tolerates anti-Semitic behavior in its ranks.

Mr. McDonnell dismisses the criticism of Mr. Corbyn, citing Labour’s 30 gains in the 650-seat House of Commons during elections in 2017 under his close ally’s leadership.

“I want to see a fundamental reshaping of the way our economy works as the first priority of a Labour government,” Mr. McDonnell said in a July speech. “Anything less will be papering over the cracks of our political and economic system.”

Write to Jason Douglas at jason.douglas@wsj.com and Max Colchester at max.colchester@wsj.com
